case_name: Karan Singh v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 55 of 1963 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 55 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated August 27, 1962,

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 27, 1962 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court Gwalior Bench in Criminal Appeal No. 18 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated August 27, 1962, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Gwalior Bench  at Gwalior in Criminal Appeal No. 18 of 1961. C. Misra, for the appellant. Al. S. K. Sastri and 1. N. Shroff, for the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant is Karan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: the present appellant Karan Singh. The case for the prosecution had at all stages been that both Ramhans and Karan Singh had gone inside the Tiwaria armed with guns and that Karan Singh throughout the incident standing by the side of Ramhans armed with a gun.

facts.text: Ramhans and six other persons including the appellant were alleged to have committed the murder of Gabde and attempted to murder Ramchandra.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Ramhans, and six other persons were alleged to have companymitted the murder of Gabde and to have attempted to murder Ramchandra. The deceased and Ramchandra are said to have belonged to one party while the alleged assailants belonged to another, and between these two parties there had been great enmity for some time past.

facts.text: Great enmity existed between the party of the deceased Gabde and Ramchandra and the party of the alleged assailants for some time past.

anchor.surface_text: The deceased and Ramchandra are said to have belonged to one party while the alleged assailants belonged to another, and between these two parties there had been great enmity for some time past. It was said that about midnight of November 18, 1959, while the deceased and Ramchandra and certain other persons were sleeping on a Tiwaria  terrace , the assailants entered the place and Ramhans shot Gabde dead with a gun and fired two shots at Ramchandra with intent to kill him but only succeeded in injuring him and that all this time the appellant was standing there armed with a gun and the other persons were also there armed variously and that all had entered the place with the companymon intention of companymitting the offences.

facts.text: About midnight of November 18, 1959, the deceased Gabde, Ramchandra and others were sleeping on a Tiwaria terrace.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that about midnight of November 18, 1959, while the deceased and Ramchandra and certain other persons were sleeping on a Tiwaria  terrace , the assailants entered the place and Ramhans shot Gabde dead with a gun and fired two shots at Ramchandra with intent to kill him but only succeeded in injuring him

facts.text: Assailants entered the Tiwaria terrace and Ramhans shot Gabde dead with a gun.

anchor.surface_text: the assailants entered the place and Ramhans shot Gabde dead with a gun and fired two shots at Ramchandra with intent to kill him but only succeeded in injuring him and that all this time the appellant was standing there armed with a gun and the other persons were also there armed variously and that all had entered the place with the companymon intention of companymitting the offences.

facts.text: Ramhans fired two shots at Ramchandra with intent to kill him but only succeeded in injuring him.

anchor.surface_text: Ramhans shot Gabde dead with a gun and fired two shots at Ramchandra with intent to kill him but only succeeded in injuring him and that all this time the appellant was standing there armed with a gun and the other persons were also there armed variously and that all had entered the place with the companymon intention of companymitting the offences. Ramhans had absconded and so the appellant and the other six alleged assailants were put up for trial for offences under ss. 302 and 307 read with ss. 148 and 149 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of Gabde and the attempt to murder Ramchandra.

facts.text: The appellant was standing there armed with a gun during the incident.

anchor.surface_text: and that all this time the appellant was standing there armed with a gun and the other persons were also there armed variously and that all had entered the place with the companymon intention of companymitting the offences. Ramhans had absconded and so the appellant and the other six alleged assailants were put up for trial for offences under ss. 302 and 307 read with ss. 148 and 149 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of Gabde and the attempt to murder Ramchandra.

facts.text: The other persons were armed variously and all had entered with common intention of committing the offences.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was standing there armed with a gun and the other persons were also there armed variously and that all had entered the place with the companymon intention of companymitting the offences. Ramhans had absconded and so the appellant and the other six alleged assailants were put up for trial for offences under ss. 302 and 307 read with ss. 148 and 149 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of Gabde and the attempt to murder Ramchandra. The learned Sessions Judge companyvicted the appellant of these offences but acquitted the other six persons tried along with him, giving them the benefit of doubt.

facts.text: Ramhans had absconded.

anchor.surface_text: Ramhans had absconded and so the appellant and the other six alleged assailants were put up for trial for offences under ss. 302 and 307 read with ss. 148 and 149 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of Gabde and the attempt to murder Ramchandra. The learned Sessions Judge companyvicted the appellant of these offences but acquitted the other six persons tried along with him, giving them the benefit of doubt.

facts.text: Appellant and other six tried for offences under ss. 302 and 307 r/w 148 and 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant and the other six alleged assailants were put up for trial for offences under ss. 302 and 307 read with ss. 148 and 149 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of Gabde and the attempt to murder Ramchandra. The learned Sessions Judge companyvicted the appellant of these offences but acquitted the other six persons tried along with him, giving them the benefit of doubt. The appellant preferred an appeal to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted the appellant of offences under ss. 302 and 307 r/w 148 and 149 but acquitted the other six giving benefit of doubt.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge companyvicted the appellant of these offences but acquitted the other six persons tried along with him, giving them the benefit of doubt. The appellant preferred an appeal to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh. After the companyviction of the appellant by the learned Sessions Judge but before his appeal companyld be heard, Ramhans had been arrested, put up for trial on the same charges and acquitted.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeal to Madhya Pradesh High Court (Criminal Appeal No. 18 of 1961).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred an appeal to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh. After the companyviction of the appellant by the learned Sessions Judge but before his appeal companyld be heard, Ramhans had been arrested, put up for trial on the same charges and acquitted. Before the High Court the appellant companytended that Ramhans having been acquitted the appellant companyld number be held companystructively liable for the offences with the aid of s. 149 of the Code.

facts.text: After Sessions Judge conviction but before appellant's appeal heard, Ramhans arrested, tried on same charges, and acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: After the companyviction of the appellant by the learned Sessions Judge but before his appeal companyld be heard, Ramhans had been arrested, put up for trial on the same charges and acquitted. Before the High Court the appellant companytended that Ramhans having been acquitted the appellant companyld number be held companystructively liable for the offences with the aid of s. 149 of the Code. The High Court rejected this companytention relying upon the judgments of this Court in Marachalil Pakku The State of Madras, 1  Bombadhar Pradhan v. State of Orissa  2  and Sunder Singh v. State of Punjab  3 .

facts.text: High Court acquitted Ramhans.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court the appellant companytended that Ramhans having been acquitted the appellant companyld number be held companystructively liable for the offences with the aid of s. 149 of the Code. The High Court rejected this companytention relying upon the judgments of this Court in Marachalil Pakku The State of Madras, 1  Bombadhar Pradhan v. State of Orissa  2  and Sunder Singh v. State of Punjab  3 .

facts.text: High Court relied on Ramchandra's direct testimony supported by Dwarka, Matadin and Maharajsingh to hold that Gabde's murder was committed by Ramhans by firing a gun at him.

anchor.surface_text: Relying on Ramchandras direct testimony as supported by Dwarka, Matadin and Maharajsingh, I would hold that Gabdes murder was companymitted by Ramhans by firing a gun at him and that Ramhans also fired two shots from his gun at Ramchandra in order to kill him. Karan Singh was at this time standing armed with a gun by the side of Ramhans I would, therefore, hold that the offence of Gabdes murder and attempt to companymit the murder of Ramchandra were companymitted by Ramhans in furtherance of the companymon intention of both himself and the present appellant Karan Singh.

facts.text: High Court held Karan Singh was standing armed with a gun by the side of Ramhans during the incident.

anchor.surface_text: Karan Singh was at this time standing armed with a gun by the side of Ramhans I would, therefore, hold that the offence of Gabdes murder and attempt to companymit the murder of Ramchandra were companymitted by Ramhans in furtherance of the companymon intention of both himself and the present appellant Karan Singh. The case for the prosecution had at all stages been that both Ramhans and Karan Singh had gone inside the Tiwaria armed with guns and that Karan Singh throughout the incident standing by the side of Ramhans armed with a gun.

facts.text: High Court convicted appellant Karan Singh under ss. 302 and 307 read with s. 34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The case for the prosecution had at all stages been that both Ramhans and Karan Singh had gone inside the Tiwaria armed with guns and that Karan Singh throughout the incident standing by the side of Ramhans armed with a gun. On these facts S. 34 I.P.C. would clearly apply to the case against the present appellant Karan Singh. In this view of the matter the High Court companyvicted the appellant Karan Singh under ss. 302 and 307 both read with S. 34 of the Code instead of the earlier sections read with ss. 148 and 149 as had been done by the learned Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal argues whether High Court could hold appellant guilty under s.302 r/w s.34 despite acquittal of Ramhans.

anchor.surface_text: The only question argued in this appeal is whether in view of the acquittal of Ramhans by the learned Sessions Judge from which there had been numberappeal, it was open to the High Court to hold that the appellant was guilty of murder under S. 302 read with S. 34 by finding on the evidence that Ramhans who shared a companymon intention with him, shot the deceased dead and attempted to murder Ramchandra.

facts.text: Ramhans was acquitted by a Sessions Judge with no appeal from that acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: is whether in view of the acquittal of Ramhans by the learned Sessions Judge from which there had been numberappeal, it was open to the High Court to hold that the appellant was guilty of murder under S. 302 read with S. 34 by finding on the evidence that Ramhans who shared a companymon intention with him, shot the deceased dead and attempted to murder Ramchandra. In the High Court reliance had been placed on behalf of the appellant on the judgment of this Court in Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab 1 .

facts.text: Prosecution case was that both Ramhans and Karan Singh went inside the Tiwaria armed with guns and Karan Singh stood by Ramhans throughout.

anchor.surface_text: The case for the prosecution had at all stages been that both Ramhans and Karan Singh had gone inside the Tiwaria armed with guns and that Karan Singh throughout the incident standing by the side of Ramhans armed with a gun. On these facts S. 34 I.P.C. would clearly apply to the case against the present appellant Karan Singh.

issues.text: whether in view of the acquittal of Ramhans by the learned Sessions Judge from which there had been no appeal, it was open to the High Court to hold that the appellant was guilty of murder under S. 302 read with S. 34 by finding on the evidence that Ramhans who shared a common intention with him, shot the deceased dead and attempted to murder Ramchandra

anchor.surface_text: The only question argued in this appeal is whether in view of the acquittal of Ramhans by the learned Sessions Judge from which there had been numberappeal, it was open to the High Court to hold that the appellant was guilty of murder under S. 302 read with S. 34 by finding on the evidence that Ramhans who shared a companymon intention with him, shot the deceased dead and attempted to murder Ramchandra.

issues.text: whether Ramhans having been acquitted the appellant could not be held constructively liable for the offences with the aid of s. 149 of the Code

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court the appellant contended that Ramhans having been acquitted the appellant could not be held constructively liable for the offences with the aid of s. 149 of the Code. The High Court rejected this contention relying upon the judgments of this Court in

issues.text: whether the decision in Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra showed that the High Court was wrong in ignoring the fact of the acquittal of Ramhans

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Misra contended that the decision of this Court in Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra 1 showed that the High Court was wrong in ignoring the fact of the acquittal of Ramhans. We are unable to accept that contention.

issues.text: whether the verdict of acquittal of Ramhans is binding and conclusive in subsequent proceedings involving the appellant

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court reliance had been placed on behalf of the appellant on the judgment of this Court in Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab 1 . That case referred with approval to the judgment of the Judicial Committee in Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor, Federation of Malaya 2 where it was observed that the effect of a verdict of acquittal is not completely stated by saying that the person acquitted cannot be tried again for the same offence. To that it must be added that the verdict is binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings between the parties to the adjudication.

issues.text: whether it is legally possible to convict under S. 302/34 after acquitting co-accused in the same trial

anchor.surface_text: The point there considered really was whether when four persons had been charged with the commission of an offence of murder read with s. 34 and the trial Court had acquitted three of them, it was legal to convict the remaining accused of the offence of murder read with s. 34. ... This is a legally impossible position.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: him, giving them the benefit of doubt. The appellant preferred an appeal to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh. After the companyvict

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court rejected relying upon judgments in Marachalil Pakku v. State of Madras, Bombadhar Pradhan v. State of Orissa and Sunder Singh v. State of Punjab

arguments.claim: Gabde's murder was committed by Ramhans by firing a gun at him and Ramhans fired two shots at Ramchandra; Karan Singh standing armed with gun by side of Ramhans; offences committed in furtherance of common intention of both; s.34 IPC applies

anchor.surface_text: Relying on Ramchandras direct testimony as supported by Dwarka, Matadin and Maharajsingh, I would hold that Gabdes murder was committed by Ramhans by firing a gun at him and that Ramhans also fired two shots from his gun at Ramchandra in order to kill him. Karan Singh was at this time standing armed with a gun by the side of Ramhans I would, therefore, hold that the offence of Gabdes murder and attempt to commit the murder of Ramchandra were committed by Ramhans in furtherance of the common intention of both himself and the present appellant Karan Singh. The case for the prosecution had at all stages been that both Ramhans and Karan Singh had gone inside the Tiwaria armed with guns and that Karan Singh throughout the incident standing by the side of Ramhans armed with a gun. On these facts S. 34 I.P.C. would clearly apply to the case against the present appellant Karan Singh.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nymit the murder of Ramchandra were companymitted by Ramhans in furtherance of the companymon intention of both himself and the present appellant Kara

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court upheld High Court's findings and application of s.34 despite Ramhans acquittal in separate trial

arguments.claim: In view of acquittal of Ramhans with no appeal, High Court could not hold appellant guilty under s.302 r/w s.34 by finding Ramhans shared common intention and committed the acts

anchor.surface_text: The only question argued in this appeal is whether in view of the acquittal of Ramhans by the learned Sessions Judge from which there had been no appeal, it was open to the High Court to hold that the appellant was guilty of murder under S. 302 read with S. 34 by finding on the evidence that Ramhans who shared a common intention with him, shot the deceased dead and attempted to murder Ramchandra.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nymit the murder of Ramchandra were companymitted by Ramhans in furtherance of the companymon intention of both himself and the present appellant Kara

arguments.court_reasoning: Acquittal in separate proceeding not binding; each case decided on its own evidence; s.34 applicable if evidence warrants

arguments.claim: Verdict of acquittal is binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings between the parties to the adjudication (per Pritam Singh and Sambasivam)

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court reliance had been placed on behalf of the appellant on the judgment of this Court in Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab 1 . That case referred with approval to the judgment of the Judicial Committee in Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor, Federation of Malaya 2 where it was observed that the effect of a verdict of acquittal is not completely stated by saying that the person acquitted cannot be tried again for the same offence. To that it must be added that the verdict is binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings between the parties to the adjudication.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: him and that Ramhans also fired two shots from his gun at Ramchandra in order to kill him. Karan Singh was a

arguments.court_reasoning: No application as acquittal of Ramhans not in proceeding to which appellant was party

arguments.claim: Observation in Sambasivam/Pritam has no application; acquittal not binding as not in proceeding involving appellant; each case turns on its own evidence; evidence in Ramhans case irrelevant to appellant's case

anchor.surface_text: As the High Court pointed out, that observation has no application to the present case as here the acquittal of Ramhans was not in any proceeding to which the appellant was a party. Clearly, the decision in each case has to turn on the evidence led in it Ramhanss case depended on the evidence led there while the appellants case had to be decided only on the evidence led in it. The evidence led in Ramhanss case and the decision there arrived at on that evidence would be wholly irrelevant in considering the merits of the appellants case.

arguments.claim: Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra shows High Court wrong in ignoring acquittal of Ramhans

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Misra contended that the decision of this Court in Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra 1 showed that the High Court was wrong in ignoring the fact of the acquittal of Ramhans. We are unable to accept that contention.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rt companyvicted the appellant Karan Singh under ss. 302 and 307 both read with S. 34 of the Code instead of the earlier sections read with ss. 148 an

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished as Krishna Govind concerned same trial leading to conflicting findings; here separate trials

arguments.claim: In Krishna Govind Patil, convicting one under s.302/34 after acquitting co-accused in same trial leads to legally impossible conflicting findings

anchor.surface_text: The point there considered really was whether when four persons had been charged with the commission of an offence of murder read with s. 34 and the trial Court had acquitted three of them, it was legal to convict the remaining accused of the offence of murder read with s. 34. The High Court had held that could be done. This Court set aside the judgment of the High Court mainly on the ground that such a decision would result in conflicting findings. It was observed, while it  the High Court  acquitted accused 1, 3 and 4 under s. 302 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code, it convicted accused 2 under S. 302 read with s. 34, of the said Code, for having committed the offence jointly with the acquitted persons. This is a legally impossible position.

arguments.claim: Krishna Govind Patil does not assist appellant; not concerned with that situation here

anchor.surface_text: That case no doubt discussed various situations where it is possible after acquitting certain persons to hold that the conviction of other or others was justified under s. 34 on the ground that the evidence showed that there were other unknown persons who were associated with those convicted though the charge did no mention them. With this aspect of the matter we are no concerned in this case and neither was the case of Krishna Govind Patil 1 . We are, therefore, of opinion that the judgment in Krishna Govind Patils 1  case does no assist the appellant at all.

arguments.claim: Judgments High Court relied on (Marachalil Pakku etc.) justify holding person guilty under s.34 with acquitted person if evidence warrants it; nothing in principle prevents; Sambasivam no application as different persons separate cases; decide on own evidence

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand we think that the judgments earlier referred to on which the High Court relied, clearly justify the view that in spite of the acquittal of a person in one case it is open to the Court in another case to proceed on the basis--of course if the evidence warrants it-that the acquitted person was guilty of the offence of which he had been tried in the other case and to find in the later case that the person tried in it was guilty of an offence under S. 34 by virtue of having committed the offence along with the acquitted person. There is nothing in principle to prevent this being done. The principle of Sambasivams 2  case has no application here because the two cases we are concerned with are against two different persons though for the commission of the same offence. Furthermore, as we have already said, each case has to be decided on the evidence led in it and this irrespective of any view of the same act that might have been taken on different evidence led in another case.

holdings.text: In spite of the acquittal of a person in one case it is open to the Court in another case to proceed on the basis--of course if the evidence warrants it--that the acquitted person was guilty of the offence of which he had been tried in the other case and to find in the later case that the person tried in it was guilty of an offence under S. 34 by virtue of having committed the offence along with the acquitted person.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand we think that the judgments earlier referred to on which the High Court relied, clearly justify the view that in spite of the acquittal of a person in one case it is open to the Court in another case to proceed on the basis--of course if the evidence warrants it-that the acquitted person was guilty of the offence of which he had been tried in the other case and to find in the later case that the person tried in it was guilty of an offence under S. 34 by virtue of having committed the offence along with the acquitted person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedents like Sambasivam and Krishna Govind Patil as inapplicable to separate trials; follows High Court-cited precedents; each trial independent on its evidence allowing finding of common intention under s.34.

holdings.text: The observation in Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor has no application to the present case as the acquittal of Ramhans was not in any proceeding to which the appellant was a party.

anchor.surface_text: As the High Court pointed out, that observation has no application to the present case as here the acquittal of Ramhans was not in any proceeding to which the appellant was a party. Clearly, the decision in each case has to turn on the evidence led in it Ramhanss case depended on the evidence led there while the appellants case had to be decided only on the evidence led in it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acquittal binding only in subsequent proceedings between same parties; here separate trials for different accused.

holdings.text: The decision in each case has to turn on the evidence led in it; the evidence led in Ramhans's case and the decision there arrived at on that evidence would be wholly irrelevant in considering the merits of the appellant's case.

anchor.surface_text: Clearly, the decision in each case has to turn on the evidence led in it Ramhanss case depended on the evidence led there while the appellants case had to be decided only on the evidence led in it. The evidence led in Ramhanss case and the decision there arrived at on that evidence would be wholly irrelevant in considering the merits of the appellants case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate trials require independent evaluation of evidence without regard to findings in other trial.

holdings.text: The judgment in Krishna Govind Patil's case does not assist the appellant at all.

anchor.surface_text: That case no doubt discussed various situations where it is possible after acquitting certain persons to hold that the conviction of other or others was justified under s. 34 on the ground that the evidence showed that there were other unknown persons who were associated with those convicted though the charge did no mention them. With this aspect of the matter we are no concerned in this case and neither was the case of Krishna Govind Patil 1 . We are, therefore, of opinion that the judgment in Krishna Govind Patils 1  case does number assist the appellant at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Krishna Govind concerned conflicting findings in same trial; inapplicable to separate trials.

holdings.text: There is nothing in principle to prevent [a court in a later case finding the acquitted person guilty based on evidence there and convicting the accused under S.34].

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in principle to prevent this being done. The principle of Sambasivams 2  case has no application here because the two cases we are concerned with are against two different persons though for the commission of the same offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No legal bar to such findings across separate proceedings; principles of issue estoppel limited to same parties.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand we think that the judgments earlier referred to on which the High Court relied, clearly justify the view that in spite of the acquittal of a person in one case it is open to the Court in another case to proceed on the basis--of course if the evidence warrants it-that the acquitted person was guilty of the offence of which he had been tried in the other case and to find in the later case that the person tried in it was guilty of an offence under S. 34 by virtue of having committed the offence along with the acquitted person.

anchor.surface_text: That case no doubt discussed various situations where it is possible after acquitting certain persons to hold that the conviction of other or others was justified under s. 34 on the ground that the evidence showed that there were other unknown persons who were associated with those convicted though the charge did no mention them. With this aspect of the matter we are no concerned in this case and neither was the case of Krishna Govind Patil 1 . We are, therefore, of opinion that the judgment in Krishna Govind Patils 1  case does number assist the appellant at all.
